title: Fix cookbook recipes

content.raw: Does `obtain_rvec` get the `center`? If not, what if I'm calculating the angular momentum relative to a different coordinate system - do I need to write a new derived field?
content.html: Does obtain_rvec get the center? If not, what if I'm calculating the angular momentum relative to a different coordinate system - do I need to write a new derived field?

content.raw: Yes, it does.
content.html: Yes, it does.

content.raw: In fact, that is precisely the bugfix.  :)
content.html: In fact, that is precisely the bugfix. :)

content.raw: Wow, good catch.
content.html: Wow, good catch.

content.raw: Of the ones I claimed, @brittonsmith is going to take a look at the variance stuff, and I do not yet know how to fix `render_with_box_and_grids.py`.  (Ping @samskillman ?)
content.html: Of the ones I claimed, Britton Smith is going to take a look at the variance stuff, and I do not yet know how to fix render_with_box_and_grids.py. (Ping Sam Skillman ?)

content.raw: Yes, getting rid of vorticity_squared makes it work, but the fact that vorticity_squared as a field doesn't work is probably indicative of a deeper problem, no?
content.html: Yes, getting rid of vorticity_squared makes it work, but the fact that vorticity_squared as a field doesn't work is probably indicative of a deeper problem, no?

content.raw: Shouldn't we come up with a way to suppress division errors for all functionality with profiles?  It's pretty worrisome to use functionality and have it tell you that you're getting div errors.
content.html: Shouldn't we come up with a way to suppress division errors for all functionality with profiles? It's pretty worrisome to use functionality and have it tell you that you're getting div errors.

content.raw: Shouldn't we do data.ds.arr, not data.pf.arr?  Or is @ngoldbaum 's new PR not accepted yet?
content.html: Shouldn't we do data.ds.arr, not data.pf.arr? Or is Nathan Goldbaum 's new PR not accepted yet?

content.raw: It's not accepted yet.  I will merge again once all this PR noise has settled down.
content.html: It's not accepted yet. I will merge again once all this PR noise has settled down.

content.raw:
It does work for periodic datasets. See my email to yt-dev for more
information.
content.html: It does work for periodic datasets. See my email to yt-dev for more information.

content.raw:
This is that way of suppressing them. I don't even like doing this, to be
honest, but I am more comfortable with it than turning off error messages.
content.html: This is that way of suppressing them. I don't even like doing this, to be honest, but I am more comfortable with it than turning off error messages.

content.raw: Why is it that we get division errors at all?
content.html: Why is it that we get division errors at all?

content.raw: Because not all the bins in the profile or phase plot are filled in.  So they have empty (zero) weights, and then when we divide by those empty (zero) weights, we are dividing by zero.  To get rid of the NaNs, we have always wiped them with zero values later (line 816) but now what I am doing is pre-flooring them so the errors are suppressed.
content.html: Because not all the bins in the profile or phase plot are filled in. So they have empty (zero) weights, and then when we divide by those empty (zero) weights, we are dividing by zero. To get rid of the NaNs, we have always wiped them with zero values later (line 816) but now what I am doing is pre-flooring them so the errors are suppressed.

content.raw: I see.  Thank you for the detailed response.  Are not all the bins in the profile/phase plot filled in simply because the bins are sub-resolution scale?  I like your solution, but do you think that it could be cleaner to include that step *in* the profile definition, instead of having to explicitly do it when generating a profile/phase plot (so that it's done automatically instead of requiring the user to do it)?
content.html: I see. Thank you for the detailed response. Are not all the bins in the profile/phase plot filled in simply because the bins are sub-resolution scale? I like your solution, but do you think that it could be cleaner to include that step in the profile definition, instead of having to explicitly do it when generating a profile/phase plot (so that it's done automatically instead of requiring the user to do it)?

content.raw: Not all of the profile bins will be filled.  For instance, imagine a phase plot.  The phase plot boundaries, even if we minimally restrain them to the bounding box of the distribution of points, will probably include regions that are unfilled.  Those unfilled regions are the zero values which we floor here.
content.html: Not all of the profile bins will be filled. For instance, imagine a phase plot. The phase plot boundaries, even if we minimally restrain them to the bounding box of the distribution of points, will probably include regions that are unfilled. Those unfilled regions are the zero values which we floor here.

content.raw: Any other suggestions, folks?  Or can this go in?
content.html: Any other suggestions, folks? Or can this go in?

content.raw: Can you delete these commented out lines and the redundant one above?
content.html: Can you delete these commented out lines and the redundant one above?

content.raw: Other than the one very minor issue I pointed out below, I see no issues.
content.html: Other than the one very minor issue I pointed out below, I see no issues.

content.raw: If it now works, you could get rid of these lines.
content.html: If it now works, you could get rid of these lines.

content.raw: Same with here; if this now works and doesn't produce a discontinuous profile, then you could remove these comments.
content.html: Same with here; if this now works and doesn't produce a discontinuous profile, then you could remove these comments.

content.raw:
It does produce a plot that is continuous. Velocities can be negative and
the recipe was logging them, which defaults to masking negative values.
This SO question has more info: http://stackoverflow.com/q/3305865/49135
content.html: It does produce a plot that is continuous. Velocities can be negative and the recipe was logging them, which defaults to masking negative values. This SO question has more info: http://stackoverflow.com/q/3305865/49135

description: This fixes all the cookbook recipes I claimed.  Note that there are three changes to the actual code to support this.  All of these need signoffs from @brittonsmith.  The Angular Momentum one is a genuine bug fix we need to get in there ASAP.
